overview: Beginning 1/1/2026, this measure requires pharmacy technicians to be registered. [6] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. [7] The measure also specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [6]
appropriations: This measure does not appropriate funds but establishes a registration fee for a pharmacy technician of $20.00 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_102, NUMBER_1] Additionally, any person who violates the provisions of this chapter or the rules adopted shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_156, NUMBER_2, NUMBER_3]
assumptions_and_methodology: The fiscal impact is based on the requirement that beginning January 1, 2026, no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid registration. [6] Revenue projections are based on a registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt) per technician. [CHUNK_102, NUMBER_1] However, given that this Act shall take effect on July 1, 3000, there is no anticipated fiscal impact within the six-year planning period. [6]
agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy will be authorized to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [6] The board will receive written notifications from pharmacists-in-charge regarding suspected violations by registered pharmacy technicians. [6] The board will have the authority to fine, suspend, or revoke any registration for causes prescribed by this chapter. [6]
economic_impact: Hawaii is the only state in the nation without an active and managed registry of practicing pharmacy technicians. [7] The regulation of pharmacy technicians is reasonably necessary to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the consumers of this State. [7] This initiative comes at a reasonable cost and represents a prudent investment in ensuring the safety, efficiency, and adaptability of our pharmacy workforce. [5]
policy_impact: This measure amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to establish a registration requirement for pharmacy technicians. [5] The committee has amended this measure by specifically exempting this measure from the requirements for a sunrise analysis by the Office of the Auditor. [7]
revenue_sources: Revenue will be generated through a registration fee for pharmacy technicians, which shall be $20.00 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_102, NUMBER_1] Each registration will be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year. [6] Additional revenue may be generated from fines, which shall be no less than $100 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_HD2_.HTM.txt) for each violation.
